image.altText: A wide scene of police in a suburban street

props.synopsis: As police investigate why Ryan Cole allegedly shot his neighbour on a suburban street in Mackay, new details have emerged about Natalie Frahm's frightening final moments and her accused killer's past filled with loss.

title.children: Accused killer Ryan Cole seemed like a friendly boat enthusiast to his neighbours. Few knew his backstory

image.altText: A man and two women pose for a photo on sandstone steps in front of an old building.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian members of the Jacqui Lambie Network had a vision to transform parliament. But is the trio living up to its name — shaking things up, bringing hard truths and keeping others accountable?

title.children: Are the Lambie MPs holding the Tasmanian government to account, or just propping it up

image.altText: a kangaroo is seen on a frosty field in canberra

props.synopsis: Parts of south-east Australia have recorded their coldest start to winter in decades, and another polar air mass during the coming week promises to bring strong winds, showers, small hail and alpine snow.

title.children: Polar outbreak and snow ahead this week with Sydney and Melbourne on track for coldest start to winter in decades

image.altText: A robot that resembles a CCTV camera is attached to the front of a research vessel.

props.synopsis: It is often said AI will take the jobs humans should be doing — but in this case, the human researchers are happy enough to pass on the job of scanning thousands of hours of recordings made deep in the Southern Ocean, freeing them up for the pursuit of scientific breakthroughs.

title.children: Meet 'Johnathan' the AI-powered camera, just one type of new technology saving the ocean's endangered animals

image.altText: A man carrying a small blonde girl

props.synopsis: Israel told Gazans in Rafah to move towards Al-Mawasi because it was a humanitarian area, but several of those who did say the aid they were promised has not arrived.

title.children: 'I am going back to Rafah, even if I die': Why Gazans are leaving a so-called 'humanitarian area'

image.altText: A photo of Cherry Park wearing a black top, and blue and beige oversized jacket, with a dark grey backdrop.

props.synopsis: Korea's notoriously high beauty standards date back hundreds of years, and even today they influence millions of men and women, with many going to extreme lengths to fit the "toxic beauty standards".

title.children: Glass skin, doe eyes, and petite figures. Why there's a dark side to Korea's 'toxic beauty standards'

image.altText: A grainy photo of a grinning man with short hair and a scarf around his neck.

props.synopsis: In what could be a costly blunder by health insurer Medibank, the Australian Information Commissioner alleges it knew about "serious deficiencies" in its IT security before hackers plundered the sensitive data of almost 10 million customers.

title.children: Medibank allegedly failed to heed IT warnings before one of Australia's worst cybersecurity breaches

image.altText: Split image shows profile of Anthony Albanese looking down, lips pursed, and Peter Dutton glancing up, squinting

props.synopsis: A surge in the polls helped spur the Coalition to announce its nuclear policy. Whether it holds on to that lead will come down to which side can persuade voters that such complex issues can magic up any short-term betterment in their lives.

title.children: A surge in the polls spurred the Coalition to announce its nuclear plans. Now both parties have a birthday cake problem

image.altText: Four musicieans singing

props.synopsis: Comedian and music lover Bec Charlwood contentiously lists the best cover songs since 1999.

title.children: From The Cranberries to Gorillaz, the top song covers of the last 25 years

image.altText: Rows of cars damaged with smashed windscreens and dented bonnets.

props.synopsis: Inflationary pressures are proving stubborn and the Reserve Bank does not want to push a fragile economy over the edge. So, are consumers in a better position to battle on the inflation front lines?

title.children: What a 15-minute phone call with my insurer taught me about how we're being charged

image.altText: A man wears a face mask and holds his hand up to his face in a three-finger salute

props.synopsis: Analysts say the so-called "deep state" that fringe groups fear in other parts of the world, is very real in Thailand.

title.children: Conspiracy theorists often talk about the 'deep state'. This is what one might actually look like

image.altText: Close up of paper EU flag burning on pavement.

props.synopsis: David Cameron took a colossal gamble on Brexit and lost. What followed was years of political chaos and division. With a general election approaching next month, did Brexit break Britain?

title.children: Is Brexit to blame for the UK's years of political uncertainty and chaos?

image.altText: Prince William leans on a rock and looks to the distance. Snow-capped mountaintops can be seen behind him.

props.synopsis: Catherine, Princess of Wales is no stranger to getting behind the camera. Here are some of her photos that give a rare peek into the lives of the royal family.

title.children: Princess Kate's candid portraits give rare view of royal family life

image.altText: Prince William jumps into the air with his three children as they hold hands

props.synopsis: The Princess of Wales posts an image of the Prince of Wales to social media for his birthday, showing William jumping in the air hand-in-hand with children George, Charlotte and Louis.

title.children: 'Happy birthday Papa': Kate Middleton releases photo of family on Prince William's birthday

image.altText: Firearms displayed, gun amnesty, weapons generic image.

props.synopsis: Australia is known for strict gun laws implemented after the Port Arthur massacre in 1996, but states and territories still have different ways of treating gun ownership. Here's a guide.

title.children: Australia has some of the strictest gun laws in the world, but how do they differ from state to state?

image.altText: A police car parked at the front of Groove Train restaurant.

props.synopsis: A wild brawl has erupted outside Epping Plaza with machetes and a firearm used. Two men believed to be involved have been hospitalised.

title.children: Police are investigating a violent brawl involving machetes and a firearm at a shopping centre in Melbourne's north

image.altText: Nuclear power station chimneys

props.synopsis: Energy sector leaders and economists say renewable energy will ultimately generate the vast share of Australia's energy mix, but nuclear could play a small role.

title.children: Business leaders open to nuclear option, but not at the expense of renewables investment

image.altText: Two older white man in legal garb stand outside a courthouse in front of a bank of microphones.

props.synopsis: An Indian-born billionaire and three family members are sentenced to prison for exploiting domestic workers at their lakeside villa in Switzerland by seizing their passports, barring them from going out and making them work up to 18 hours a day.

title.children: Billionaire family members sentenced to four-year prison terms for exploiting domestic workers in Switzerland

image.altText: A group of Pakistani men and boys stand around a pile of burnt rocks and wood in a town square.

props.synopsis: The tourist, identified as Mohammad Ismail, was being questioned by police when the mob attacked the police station, officers said.

title.children: Pakistan police hunting mob that lynched and burned tourist suspected of desecrating Koran

image.altText: A woman with a green top sits at a desk with paperwork and phone, her hair is over her face and hand on the side of head.

props.synopsis: If you're renting, you'll know that rental increases are a fact of life. But you do have options if you think your landlord (or their agent) is asking for too much.

title.children: How do I fight a rental increase from my landlord?

image.altText: Michael Richards as Kramer pointing to an illustrated portrait of himself

props.synopsis: It's hard to imagine another actor playing Kramer. Michael Richards owned the Seinfeld character in such a way he found it difficult to convince the industry he could play any other parts once the show wrapped up. Richards takes readers behind the scenes of the popular sitcom in his memoir Entrances and Exits.

title.children: How Michael Richards became Kramer and made a disposable character integral to Seinfeld

image.altText: An older man with grey hair and a beard smiles in a white rose garden, with a flower lapelled to his red rose-printed suit.

props.synopsis: Donald Sutherland's wry, arresting screen presence has spanned more than half a century. From The Hunger Games to M*A*S*H, here are seven of his most celebrated performances.

title.children: From The Hunger Games to M*A*S*H, here are seven of Donald Sutherland's most celebrated performances

image.altText: A woman leans against a tree.

props.synopsis: Victoria's health minister has described the treatment of an Aboriginal woman who self-discharged from hospital as "shocking", while government data shows an increase in the number of First Peoples leaving hospitals against medical advice

title.children: Sissy Austin was confused and concussed after a violent assault. She was discharged onto the street at 1am

image.altText: A woman embracing outside of court

props.synopsis: Andrew Thomas Hayler, 38, is sentenced to nine years in jail for uploading digitally altered images of dozens of women he knew, alongside identifying details, to a pornography website.

title.children: 'He deserves it': Sydney man jailed for uploading altered photos of his friends to porn site

image.altText: A woman wearing a white singlet top sits on a chair next to her crutches.

props.synopsis: Michelle Wardrope's family was told to prepare for her funeral after the 44-year-old mother contracted a rare and deadly bacterial infection from a minor cut.

title.children: Michelle cut her leg when she slipped on her driveway. After two weeks in a coma, she's now an amputee

image.altText: Protesters wearing yellow headbands gather and sing songs, with many holding mobile phones aloft.

props.synopsis: The new guidelines urge Chinese institutions to defend national sovereignty, but China has no jurisdiction over Taiwan.

title.children: Taiwan slams China's threats to impose death penalty on independence activists

image.altText: A bull rider in full flight at an outback rodeo.

props.synopsis: Bull-riding is a hugely popular sport in Australia, known for large crowds, big hats and plenty of close calls. But what many spectators don't see is what goes on at properties across the country to prepare the bulls for their time on the big stage.

title.children: Bull-riding is a controversial sport, but it's only banned in one Australian jurisdiction

image.altText: An aerial view of Ashley Youth Detention Centre.

props.synopsis: Tasmanians who were abused as children in the notorious Ashley youth detention centre reach an in-principle agreement to settle their class action with the state government.

title.children: Former detainees abused at Tasmania's Ashley youth detention centre reach $75m deal

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff appears to be in thought, surrounded by his colleagues.

props.synopsis: Dramatic sighs, sarcastic laughter, rhetorical questions. Parliamentary performances aren't new, but with multiple non-government bills passed this week, Tasmanian politicians showed they can collaborate — well, sort of.

title.children: 'This is democracy in action': Why Tasmania's collaborative new parliament is a win for voters

image.altText: Front on view of an icebreaker ship.

props.synopsis: In the wake of tensions between the federal and Tasmanian governments over the redevelopment of the RSV Nuyina's base in Hobart, WA says it's open to discussions about the future of the Australian Antarctic Program.

title.children: Hobart is Antarctic icebreaker Nuyina's home port — but a funding stoush has put WA on the radar

image.altText: A man wearing a hi-vis vest with the message I SPEAK ENGLISH AND POLISH written on it speaks with a group

props.synopsis: Poland's response to the human tide from Ukraine is already a case study in effective crisis management. But dealing with Russian disinformation — now morphing into subversion and outright sabotage — has been a consistent problem.

title.children: 'They are relentless': On the front lines of Russia's disinformation war

image.altText: Grey stingray in water

props.synopsis: Using drones, aerial imagery, and 3D modelling to map and identify stingray feeding pits on the estuary floor, a study has found they play a significant role in health of estuarine ecosystems.

title.children: Stingrays' decline could spell trouble for delicate estuarine ecosystems, fisheries

image.altText: Two kids lying on grass surrounded by empty bottles and cans

props.synopsis: After experiencing homelessness, siblings Annabelle and Sunny Johnson started collecting the neighbourhood's bottles and cans to buy a block of land. It's a lofty goal but their mum is proof that it's possible to achieve after buying a home on her own.

title.children: These kids are collecting cans for cash not to buy lollies or toys, but a block of land

props.synopsis: After more than seven years on a waiting list, Christie Lewis is finally moving to a house that's suited to her needs. But she's facing a big bill to repair the damage caused to her existing rental by her wheelchair.

title.children: Woman facing big damage repair bill because her rental home wasn't big enough for her wheelchair

image.altText: A dirt road barred by high vis markers and a sign saying 'closed'

props.synopsis: A crime scene has been established in Gellibrand Lower after the bodies of a man and a woman were found on a walking track near Wreck Beach.

title.children: Man and woman found dead on walking track near Victoria's Great Ocean Road, police say
